title: The Factory of Forgetfulness
theme: A mysterious factory where memories are processed, stored, and sometimes deliberately lost
narrative_arc: Trapped inside → Solid walls → Country borders → Round objects → Cause unknown → Park entrance → Return attempted → Revolving doors → Picture incomplete → Store nearby → Warehouse full → Trousers stocked → Factory operating → Bed for rest → Hemp processing → Heart beating → Forgetting begins → Endurance tested → Recognition fading → Aspiration lost → Annals written → Consideration deep → Ideas forming → Thinking slows → Breath shortens → Fear rises → Feeling returns → Regret accumulates → Worry spreads → Dread grows → Busy always → Accustomed now → Cherishing what remains → Certainly this
narrative_story: The factory produced one thing: forgetting. Everyone who entered became trapped inside its walls. The walls were solid as certainty. The country that contained it had no borders on maps. Everything inside was round — no corners to hide memories in. No one knew the cause of the forgetting. There was a park at the entrance, peaceful and misleading. Many tried to return to their old lives. But the doors revolved — entry was easier than exit. Every picture on the walls was incomplete. A store nearby sold remedies that never worked. The warehouse was full of forgotten things. Even trousers hung on hooks, abandoned. The factory never stopped operating. A bed was provided for rest between forgetting sessions. Hemp ropes bound the memories scheduled for deletion. Your heart would beat faster in the deletion chamber. Forgetting began slowly, then accelerated. Endurance was tested — how much could you lose? Recognition faded — faces became strangers. Aspiration was among the first things lost. The annals of your life were rewritten blank. Deep consideration of your past became impossible. Ideas that once defined you began forming into mist. Thinking slowed to a crawl. Breath shortened as panic set in. Fear rose from forgotten depths. But then — feeling returned, different but present. Regret accumulated for things you couldn't name. Worry spread for people you no longer recognized. Dread grew for a future without past. You were always busy now, busy forgetting. Eventually, you became accustomed to the emptiness. What remained, you began cherishing desperately. Certainly, this was a kind of peace. The factory had done its work. You had forgotten how to remember. And in forgetting, you had found something else. What it was, you could never quite recall.
